case_name: Sajjan Singh v. State of Punjab

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 20, 1960 of the Punjab High Court
A case under s. 45 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 was registered on the basis of this complaint

issues.text: whether on the evidence on the record a presumption under s. 5(3) of the Prevention of Corruption Act arose

anchor.surface_text: We shall first consider the question whether on the evidence on the record a presumption under s. 5 3  of the Prevention of Corruption Act arose. It is useful to remember that the first sub-section of s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act mentions in the four clauses a, b, c and d, the acts on the commission of which a public servant is said to have committed an offence of criminal misconduct in the discharge of his duties.

issues.text: whether pecuniary resources and property acquired before March 11, 1947, when the Prevention of Corruption Act came into force, could be taken into consideration for the purpose of s. 5(3) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The two learned judges of the Punjab High Court who heard the appeal differed on the question whether pecuniary resources and property acquired before- March 11, 1947, when the Prevention of Corruption Act came into force, could be taken into consideration for the purpose of s. 5  3  of the Act.

issues.text: whether sub-section (3) of s.5 creates a new offence of criminal misconduct different from those defined in clauses (a), (b), (c) and (d) of s.5(1)

anchor.surface_text: Notice must be taken in this connection of a suggestion made by the learned Counsel that in effect sub-section 3 of section 5 creates a new offence in the discharge of official duty, different from what is defined in the four clauses of s. 5 l .

issues.text: whether the Act has retrospective operation such that pre-Act assets cannot be considered under s.5(3)

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the learned Counsel that the Act has no retrospective operation. We are unable to agree however that to take into consideration the pecuniary resources or property in the possession of the accused or any other person on his behalf which are acquired before the date of the Act is in any way giving the Act a retrospective operation.

issues.text: whether presumption under s.5(3) can arise if the prosecution has adduced other evidence in support of its case

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it was contended by Mr. Lall that no presumption under s. 5 3  can arise if the prosecution has adduced other evidence in support of its case. According to the learned Counsel, s. 5 3  is at the most an alternative mode of establishing the guilt of the accused which can be availed of only if the usual method of proving his guilt by direct and circumstantial evidence is not used.

issues.text: whether the entries in the account books are relevant under s.34 of the Indian Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: In support of the appeal Mr. 1. M. Lall has attacked the finding that the books of account were kept regularly in the course of business and has contended that the entries therein were not relevant under s. 34 of the Indian Evidence Act.

issues.text: whether the fact of certain admitted entries being interspersed through the books of account furnishes independent corroboration for the accomplices' evidence

anchor.surface_text: He further contended that even if they be relevant evidence the Special judge as also the High Court while rightly thinking that they by themselves did not amount to independent corroboration, were in error when they thought that the fact of certain admitted entries being interspersed through the books of account furnished the necessary independent corroboration.

arguments.claim: Entries in the account books are not relevant under s.34 of the Indian Evidence Act because the books were not kept regularly in the course of business

anchor.surface_text: In support of the appeal Mr. 1. M. Lall has attacked the finding that the books of account were kept regularly in the course of business and has contended that the entries therein were not relevant under s. 34 of the Indian Evidence Act.

arguments.claim: Even if account book entries are relevant, the fact of certain admitted entries being interspersed does not furnish independent corroboration for the accomplices' evidence

anchor.surface_text: He further contended that even if they be relevant evidence the Special judge as also the High Court while rightly thinking that they by themselves did not amount to independent corroboration, were in error when they thought that the fact of certain admitted entries being interspersed through the books of account furnished the necessary independent corroboration.

arguments.claim: Pecuniary resources or property acquired before the Prevention of Corruption Act came into force cannot be taken into consideration under s.5(3) as that would give the Act retrospective operation

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Lall contends that when the section speaks of the accused being in possession of pecuniary resources or pro- perty disproportionate to his known sources of income only pecuniary resources or property acquired after the date of the Act is meant. To think otherwise, says the learned Counsel, would be to give the Act retrospective operation

court_response_anchor.surface_text: guilt of the accused in criminal proceedings lies all the way on the prosecution. Under the provision of this subsection the burden on the prosecutio

arguments.court_reasoning: Act has no retrospective operation but including pre-Act assets in possession does not make it retrospective as requisites drawn from antecedent time; cites Maxwell

arguments.claim: Sub-section (3) of s.5 creates a new offence of criminal misconduct different from those defined in clauses (a), (b), (c) and (d) of s.5(1)

anchor.surface_text: Notice must be taken in this connection of a suggestion made by the learned Counsel that in effect sub-section 3 of section 5 creates a new offence in the discharge of official duty, different from what is defined in the four clauses of s. 5 l .

arguments.court_reasoning: s.5(3) merely prescribes a rule of evidence for proving offence defined in s.5(1); cites D.S. Swamy and Surajpal Singh

arguments.claim: Conviction under s.5(3) based on pre-Act assets would breach fundamental rights under Art.20(1) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: If this argument were correct a conviction of a person under the presumption raised under the s. 5 3  in respect of pecuniary resources or property acquired before the Prevention of Corruption Act would be a breach of fundamental rights under Art. 20 l  of the Constitution

court_response_anchor.surface_text: cquisition. If this argument were companyrect a companyviction of a person under the presumption raised under the s. 5 3  in respect of pecuniary reso

arguments.court_reasoning: Argument unsound as s.5(3) is rule of evidence for post-Act offence trial

arguments.claim: s.5(3) is meaningless because every pecuniary resource or property is itself a source of income, so cannot be disproportionate to known sources of income

anchor.surface_text: Mention has next to be made of the learned Counsels submission that the section is meaningless. According to the learned Counsel, every pecuniary resource or property is itself a source of income and therefore it is a contra dic- tion in terms to say that the pecuniary resources or pro- perty can be disproportionate to the known sources of income.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: pears to be about Rs. 10,000/-. The total receipts by the appellant from his known sources of income thus appears to be about Rs. 1,03,000/-. If numbe

arguments.court_reasoning: Pecuniary resources/property regarded as assets at a point of time to check against income yield including past property

arguments.claim: No presumption under s.5(3) arises if prosecution has adduced other evidence; it is only an alternative mode if no direct/circumstantial evidence used

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it was contended by Mr. Lall that no presumption under s. 5 3  can arise if the prosecution has adduced other evidence in support of its case. According to the learned Counsel, s. 5 3  is at the most an alternative mode of establishing the guilt of the accused which can be availed of only if the usual method of proving his guilt by direct and circumstantial evidence is not used.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: would justify us in interfering with these. The prosecution has thus proved facts on which it becomes the duty of the Court to assume that the accused

arguments.court_reasoning: No such limiting words as 'absence of evidence'; distinguishes Del Vecchio (US case has 'absence of substantial evidence') and Bratty

arguments.claim: Pecuniary resources and property held by wife and son not on behalf of appellant; total in his possession less than Rs.50,000 not disproportionate to known sources

anchor.surface_text: The main defence of the appellant as regards this allegation of possession of pecuniary resources and property disproportionate to his known sources of income was that the property and pecuniary resources held by his wife and son were not held on his behalf and that what, was in his possession amounted to less than Rs. 50,000/- and can by no means be said to be disproportionate

arguments.court_reasoning: Evidence shows son held on behalf (rejected stories of Udhe Singh, grandfather gifts); total >1,20,000 disproportionate to ~67,000 net income after expenses

arguments.claim: Pre-1947 assets cannot be considered under s.5(3)

anchor.surface_text: In the opinion of Mr. Justice Harbans Singh these could not be taken into consideration-. Taking into consideration the assets acquired by the appellant after January 1948 the learned judges held that these came to just above Rs. 20,000/- and could not be held to be disproportionate to his known sources of income.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ount in the Bank of Patiala at Doraha and  5  Half share in a plot of land in Ludhiana of the value Rs. 11,000/-. Bhupinder Singh has given evidence

arguments.court_reasoning: All assets in possession at check date includable regardless of acquisition time; no justification to add words limiting to post-Act

arguments.claim: Pre-1947 assets must be included under s.5(3) if in possession at complaint date; disproportionate even excluding some periods

anchor.surface_text: The other learned Judge, Mr. Justice Capoor, was of opinion that pecuniary resources and property acquired prior to March 11, 1947 had also to be taken into consideration in applying s. 5  3  of the Prevention of Corruption Act if they were in the possession of the accused or anybody on his behalf, on the date when the complaint was lodged.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ount in the Bank of Patiala at Doraha and  5  Half share in a plot of land in Ludhiana of the value Rs. 11,000/-. Bhupinder Singh has given evidence

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees; plain words require all possession considered; cites Maxwell on antecedent requisites

arguments.claim: Account book entries relevant under s.34 Evidence Act; interspersing admitted payments provides independent corroboration for accomplices

anchor.surface_text: The learned Special judge rejected the defence contention that the account books on which the prosecution relied had not been kept regularly in the course of business and held the entries therein to be relevant under s. 34 of the Indian Evidence Act. He accepted the defence contention that evidence of the partners who were in the position of accomplices required independent corroboration

arguments.claim: Presumption under s.5(3) arises on proof of disproportionate assets in possession including those held by wife/son on behalf; not rebutted

anchor.surface_text: the first sub-section of s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act mentions in the four clauses a, b, c and d, the acts on the commission of which a public servant is said to have committed an offence of criminal misconduct in the discharge of his duties. ... He concluded that the presumption under s. 5 3  of the Prevention of Corruption Act was attracted.

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirms disproportion >120k vs net 67k; explanations untrustworthy; presumption arises and not rebutted

arguments.claim: s.5(3) provides additional mode of proof via presumption on disproportionate assets; shifts burden to accused; valid even solely based thereon; includes all assets in possession

anchor.surface_text: This sub-section thus provides an additional mode of proving an offence punishable under sub-s. 2 for which any accused person is being tried. This additional mode is by proving the extent of the pecuniary resources or property in the possession of the accused or any other person on his behalf and thereafter showing that this is disproportionate to his known sources of income

arguments.claim: Strict construction of s.5(3) required but no adding words to exclude pre-Act assets; plain meaning includes all possession

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that the language of such a special provision must be strictly construed. if the words are capable of two constructions, one of which is more favorable to the accused than the other, the Court will be justified in accepting the one which is more favourable to the accused.

arguments.claim: Minimum sentence of one year RI required under s.5(2); no special reasons to reduce

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, Mr. Lall prayed that the sentence be reduced. The sentence imposed on the appellant is one years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 5,000/-. Under s. 5 2  the minimum sentence has to be one years imprisonment, subject to the proviso that the Court may for special reasons to be recorded in writing, impose a sentence of imprisonment of less than one year.

holdings.text: Pecuniary resources and property acquired before the Prevention of Corruption Act came into force must be taken into consideration under s.5(3) if in possession of the accused or on his behalf at the relevant date.

anchor.surface_text: From whatever point we look at the matter it seems to us clear that the pecuniary resources and property in the possession of the accused person or any other person on his behalf have to be taken into consideration for the purpose of sub- section 3 of section 5, whether these were acquired before or after the Act came into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.5(3) requires all assets in possession; no justification to add limiting words; strict construction but no dilution; cites Maxwell on antecedent requisites; hypothetical exclusion leads to anomaly.

holdings.text: The Act has no retrospective operation, but considering pre-Act assets in possession under s.5(3) does not give it retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the learned Counsel that the Act has no retrospective operation. We are unable to agree however that to take into consideration the pecuniary resources or property in the possession of the accused or any other person on his behalf which are acquired before the date of the Act is in any way giving the Act a retrospective operation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requisites drawn from antecedent time not retrospective; cites Maxwell; agrees Act not retrospective but possession snapshot includes pre-Act.

holdings.text: s.5(3) does not create a new offence of criminal misconduct; it merely prescribes a rule of evidence for proving offences defined in s.5(1).

anchor.surface_text: The basis of the argument that s. 5 3  creates a new kind of offence of criminal misconduct by a public servant in the discharge of his official duty is however unsound. The sub-section does nothing of the kind. It merely prescribes a rule of evidence for the purpose of proving the offence of criminal misconduct as defined in s. 5 1

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5(3) aids proof of s.5(1) offences post-Act; new mode in ongoing trial; cites D.S. Swamy and Surajpal Singh; rejects Art.20 violation.

holdings.text: Presumption under s.5(3) can arise even if prosecution adduces other evidence; no requirement of absence of evidence.

anchor.surface_text: For this astonishing proposition we can find no support either in principle or authority... These or similar words are conspicuous by their absence in sub-s. 3 of s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, and consequently, Del Vecchio's Case is of no assistance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No words like 'absence of substantial evidence'; distinguishes Del Vecchio and Bratty; presumption independent, shifts burden after disproportion proved.

holdings.text: Presumption under s.5(3) arises on the facts: disproportionate assets in possession (including those held by wife/son on behalf) not satisfactorily explained.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Total assets >Rs.1,20,000 vs net known income ~Rs.67,000; explanations (Udhe Singh, gifts) disbelieved; burden shifts, not rebutted; conviction solely on presumption valid.

holdings.text: Conviction solely on s.5(3) presumption is valid even if other evidence insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: the conviction for an offence of criminal misconduct shall not be invalid by reason only that it is based solely on such presumption. This is a deliberate departure from the ordinary principle... Under the provision of this subsection the burden on the prosecution to prove the guilt... shifts to the accused

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit statutory language; affirms s.5(3) as additional proof mode; distinguishes Surajpal on charge mismatch.

holdings.text: No special reasons to reduce minimum sentence of one year RI under s.5(2).

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see anything that would justify us in taking action under the proviso.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Minimum mandatory absent special recorded reasons; none found.

precedents.citation: State of Maharashtra v. Vishnu Ramchandra l

anchor.surface_text: See also State of Maharashtra v. Vishnu Ramchandra l  . Notice must be taken in this connection of a suggestion made by the learned Counsel that in effect sub-section 3 of section 5 creates a new offence in the discharge of official duty, different from what is defined in the four clauses of s. 5 l . It is said that the act of being in possession of pecuniary resources or pro-

precedents.case_name: State of Maharashtra v Vishnu Ramchandra
precedents.cited_proposition: A statute cannot be said to be retrospective because a part of the requisites for its action is drawn from a time antecedent to its passing

anchor.surface_text: It was so held by this Court in D.S. Swamy v. The State 1  and again in Surajpal Singh v. State of U.p. 2 . It is only when a trial has commenced for criminal misconduct by doing one or more of the acts mentioned in cls. a, b, c and d of s. 5 (1) that sub-s 3 can come into operation.

precedents.cited_proposition: Sub-section 3 of section 5 merely prescribes a rule of evidence for proving the offence of criminal misconduct as defined in s. 5(1), does not create a new offence

precedents.citation: Surajpal Singh v. State of U.p. 2

anchor.surface_text: and again in Surajpal Singh v. State of U.p. 2 . It is only when a trial has commenced for criminal misconduct by doing one or more of the acts mentioned in cls. a, b, c and d of s. 5 (1) that sub-s 3 can come into operation. When there is such a trial, which necessarily must be in respect of acts committed after the Prevention of Corruption Act came into force, sub-section 3 places in the hands of the prosecution a new mode of proving an offence with which an accused has already been charged.

precedents.case_name: Surajpal Singh v State of UP
precedents.cited_proposition: Sub-section 3 of section 5 merely prescribes a rule of evidence for proving the offence of criminal misconduct as defined in s. 5(1), does not create a new offence

anchor.surface_text: As was held by this Court in Swamys Case 1  the expression known sources of income must have reference to sources known to the prosecution on a thorough investigation of the case and that it could not be contended that known sources of income meant sources known to the accused.

precedents.cited_proposition: Known sources of income has reference to sources known to the prosecution on thorough investigation, not sources known only to the accused

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn in this connection to this Courts decision in Surajpal Singhs Case 1  where this Court set aside the conviction of the appellant Surajpal Singh on the basis of the presumption under s. 5 (3) . What happened in that case was that though the accused had been charged with having committed the offence of criminal misconduct in the discharge of his duty by doing the acts mentioned in cl.  c  of sub-s. 1 of s. 5, the Special Judge and the High Court convicted him by invoking the rule of presumption laid down in sub-s. 3 of s. 5, of an offence under cl.  d  of s. 5 (1) .

precedents.case_name: Surajpal Singh v State of UP
precedents.cited_proposition: Presumption under s.5(3) cannot be used to convict for a different type of criminal misconduct than the one charged under specific clause of s.5(1)

anchor.surface_text: For this astonishing proposition we can find no support either in principle or authority. Mr. Lall sought assistance for his arguments from a decision of the Supreme Court of the United States of America in D. Del Vecchio v. Botvers 1 . What fell to be considered in that case was whether a presumption created by s. 20 (d) of the Longshoremens and Harbor Workers Compensation Act that the death of an employee was not suicidal arose where evidence had been adduced by both sides on the question whether the death was suicidal or not.

precedents.cited_proposition: Presumption falls out once opposing evidence is adduced; only operates in absence of substantial evidence

anchor.surface_text: These or similar words are conspicuous by their absence in sub-s. 3 of s. 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, and consequently, Del Vec- chios Case 1  is of no assistance.

precedents.cited_proposition: Presumption only where no substantial evidence to contrary

precedents.citation: Bratty v. Attorney General for Northern Ireland 2

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Lall then drew our attention to an observation of Lord Denning in Bratty v. Attorney General for Northern Ireland 2  where speaking about the presumption that every man has sufficient mental capacity to be responsible for his crimes, the Lord Justice observed that the presumption takes the place of evidence.

precedents.case_name: Bratty v Attorney General for Northern Ireland
precedents.cited_proposition: A presumption takes the place of evidence

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant's conviction under s. 5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act and sentence of 1 year RI and Rs.5000 fine upheld; prayer for sentence reduction rejected
